title: Understanding Endometriosis
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value:
Endometriosis is a condition where tissue similar to the lining of the uterus grows outside the uterus. It can cause **chronic pain**, **fertility issues**, and significantly impact quality of life.

Understanding the symptoms and treatment options can help you take control of your health.

content.title: Key Facts
content.description: Approximately 1 in 10 women of reproductive age are affected by endometriosis. Early diagnosis and treatment can help manage symptoms and protect fertility.

content.text: Recognising the signs and when to seek help

items.title: Painful Periods
items.description: Severe menstrual cramps that may worsen over time

items.title: Pain During Sex
items.description: Discomfort during or after sexual intercourse

items.title: Urination Pain
items.description: Pain when urinating, especially during periods

items.title: Bowel Issues
items.description: Pain during bowel movements, particularly during menstruation

content.title: Important Reminder
content.description: Many women believe severe period pain is "normal" - it isn't. You don't have to live with it. If you experience these symptoms, please consult with a healthcare provider.

content.text: Understanding how endometriosis affects different aspects of life

content.value: Endometriosis can affect different aspects of life. Understanding its impact helps in finding the right treatment and support.

items.title: Fertility Impact
items.description: Endometriosis can make it harder to get pregnant, but many women still conceive naturally. Early diagnosis and treatment can help protect your fertility options.

items.title: Emotional Wellbeing
items.description: Symptoms can affect your emotional health and quality of life. It's important to seek support and early treatment for both physical and mental wellbeing.

content.text: The exact cause is unknown, but research suggests several possible factors

items.title: Retrograde Menstruation
items.description: Backward flow of menstrual blood into the pelvic cavity

items.title: Genetics
items.description: Family history may increase your risk

items.title: Hormonal Imbalances
items.description: Hormone-related factors that affect tissue growth

content.value: Diagnosing endometriosis can be challenging as symptoms vary widely. On average, it takes **7-10 years** from the onset of symptoms to receive a diagnosis.

items.text: Average diagnosis time: 7-10 years from first symptoms
Multiple tests may be required for confirmation
Early diagnosis leads to better treatment outcomes

content.title: Why Early Diagnosis Matters
content.description: Early detection can prevent disease progression, preserve fertility, and improve quality of life through timely treatment.

steps: Pelvic Examination - Your doctor will perform a physical examination to check for abnormalities.
Imaging Tests - Ultrasound or MRI scans to look for signs of endometriosis and cysts.
Laparoscopy - A minor keyhole surgery using a thin camera to confirm diagnosis and sometimes take tissue samples.

content.text: Personalised treatment plans tailored to your needs

items.title: Pain Relief Medication
items.description: Over-the-counter or prescription pain medications to manage symptoms.

items.title: Hormone Therapy
items.description: Treatments to slow or stop endometrial tissue growth.

items.title: Conservative Surgery
items.description: Removal of endometriosis tissue while preserving reproductive organs.

items.title: Hysterectomy
items.description: Considered only if other treatments haven't helped and you're not planning future pregnancies.

content.title: Personalised Care
content.description: We'll work closely with you to find the right balance of treatment based on your symptoms and goals.
